items.title: What Constitutes Good and Bad Web Design?
items.abstract: Well-crafted sites need to fulfill their functions efficiently and engagingly.

items.title: Rendering a City With a Blowtorch
items.abstract: Belarus Free Theater offers a scathing mosaic of its home city with “Minsk, 2011,” at the Under the Radar festival at the Public Theater.

items.title: City Jobs Lost in Storm Are Returning, but Unemployment Rate Is Flat
items.abstract: The State Labor Department reported that more than half of the jobs lost in November were added back in New York City, and unemployment remained at 8.8 percent.

items.title: Despite a Whiff of Unpleasant Exaggeration, a City’s Pollution Is Real
items.abstract: No scientific evidence supports persistent tales that the air in Kabul, Afghanistan’s capital, has the world’s highest level of feces.

items.title: Developing Education Initiatives for City’s Young Mexican Immigrants
items.abstract: A foundation’s efforts are progressing, with 17 proposals for preliminary grants now under review.

items.title: Rural Oregon’s Lost Prosperity Gives Standoff a Distressed Backdrop
items.abstract: Areas that were once economically important languish as jobs are clustered in urban centers, creating a feeling of powerlessness as their populations grow older, poorer and less educated.

items.title: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
items.abstract: Sustainable housing plans have transformed Hammarby Sjostad, a neighborhood in Stockholm. Now, new cultural projects are providing another boost.

items.title: Tears and Bewilderment in Brazilian City Facing Zika Crisis
items.abstract: The Zika epidemic has spread much faster than science’s understanding of it.

items.title: Reps in the City That Has No Rest Days
items.abstract: A daylong stakeout at Synergy Fitness, a 24-hour gym, reveals the city’s workout rhythms.

items.title: Colonial Architecture Fades From Ho Chi Minh City, and Residents Mourn
items.abstract: As many historic buildings are razed to make way for the new, residents have started Facebook groups dedicated to celebrating and protecting them.

items.title: Mayor de Blasio Says Wealth Is ‘in the Wrong Hands,’ Pledges to Redistribute It
items.abstract: In his State of the City address, Mayor Bill de Blasio offered progressive promises and a new ferry between Staten Island and Manhattan’s West Side.

items.title: N.Y. Draws a Record 65 Million Tourists (in Spite of Trump’s Trade War, Many Were Chinese)
items.abstract: The number of visitors to New York City climbed for the ninth year, led by tourists from the United States, the United Kingdom, China and Canada.

items.title: New York Needs Amazon
items.abstract: History is clear: A city that rejects economic opportunity will lose its status as the center of the business world.

items.title: South Asia Is Smothered in Toxic Air, Report Finds
items.abstract: A global study from Greenpeace and a software company found that India, Bangladesh and Pakistan had the most polluted air.

items.title: Segregation Has Been the Story of New York City’s Schools for 50 Years
items.abstract: Low black and Hispanic enrollment at Stuyvesant High School has reignited a debate about how to finally integrate the city’s schools.

items.title: India’s budget focuses on roads, but critics see need for more jobs.
items.abstract: Narendra Modi’s plan calls for a big increase in infrastructure spending. Some say more must be done to create jobs for the country’s young work force.

items.title: How New York City’s Hospitals Withstood the Omicron Surge
items.abstract: The highly contagious coronavirus variant stretched the city’s health care system to the breaking point, but not past it.

items.title: A Million More Trees for New York City: Leaders Want a Greener Canopy
items.abstract: The city’s five borough presidents are also urging the mayor to honor a pledge to spend 1 percent of the municipal budget on parks.

items.title: Which Cities Are Best for Walking Your Dog?
items.abstract: A study ranked cities based on data across numerous metrics.

items.title: He’s Springing Forward to Move City Clocks to Daylight Time
items.abstract: Marvin Schneider, the New York City clock master, has a busy weekend ahead.
